concern:
Hi all,

I am an MBA student in the back half of my program with 4 classes left. I am in the second most challenging class in the degree supposedly at the moment, and while it is a lot of work it didn't seem tough when given the time at the beginning of the semester. The issue is, I haven't been able to put the time in to succeed and it is really hitting me mentally, I can't decide what to do at the moment. 

I recently lost both my great aunt and uncle (basically my grandparents, the closest people in my life outside of my immediate family) within two weeks of each other and have had to travel across the USA to support my family and be there as my aunt passed away at the end. For reference, my aunt and uncle lived in the northeast while my family is located in southern FL. My immediate family is extremely close and my mother has been away from the family providing care every step of the way in conjunction with Hospice, not leaving their side since her arrival there in early September. On top of this, my maternal grandparents and maternal uncle (who have been mentally abusive of my mother for my entire life, the reason we moved down south) have been treating the family terribly and causing additional stress for my family and quite frankly I don't know how my mother has been able to deal with this whole thing. My uncle is a troublemaker who has been enabled throughout his life by my grandparents and has been to jail a few times for various issues that should have landed him more time in lockup. The conflict this time is over the fact certain people were not included in the will, and my mom is being blamed for us having control of the estate. We had a bat by the door the whole time we were at my great aunt and uncle's house and all decided nobody is leaving mom alone and we needed to be ready in case he showed up to cause issues. 

I say all this to mention that while I stayed there (4 weeks) from the beginning of October to a few days ago, I had no access to the internet on the trip minus randomly stopping at a local community college to try and do some work one day for class. Essentially every waking moment I was there I was with the family and trying to provide support for my mom, and I lost track of this class and got so far behind that I feel like I can't claw my way back at this point. I can drop the course, but I feel as if I am an abject failure for doing so. I thought about dropping earlier in the trip but figured I'd be able to get back on track when we left, but we stayed longer than anticipated and I feel as if that isn't the case.

 I'm 26 and feel like I should be done with my degree already, I don't want to put myself back by a semester when I am nearing the finish line, but I'm not sure what to do. I haven't completely coped with the situation to this point and am just looking for some insights or perspective on this. I am planning on having a conversation over the phone with my professor on Thursday, and my advisor has mentioned I can get out of the class affecting my degree given the circumstances. It still just makes me feel like I'm screwing myself so hard and wasting time. 

Sorry for being long-winded. 

Got any ways to deal with the guilt of potentially dropping a class, and have any advice?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm so glad you're here. Please feel free to share whatever's been on your mind or heart lately. I'm here to listen and support you without judgment.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve just been really overwhelmed lately with personal stuff and school, and I’m struggling to figure out how to handle it all.
That sounds really tough. It can be hard to balance everything when life gets overwhelming. Do you want to tell me more about what's been going on with school and your personal life?
Hey, yeah, I’d like to dive into it a bit. I’ve just got this heavy mix of family issues and falling behind in a tough class, and it’s really messing with my head trying to decide what to do next.
I can only imagine how hard it must be to juggle family issues and school stress at the same time. It sounds like you're feeling really stuck right now, and that must be incredibly frustrating.

client: Yeah, exactly, I just feel completely stuck and like I’m failing at everything. I’m so close to finishing my degree, but this one class and all the family chaos are making me question if I can even keep going.

It's really admirable that you're so close to finishing your degree, especially considering all the challenges you're facing right now. Can you tell me more about what keeps you motivated to keep going, even with everything going on?

client: Hey, thanks for saying that. Honestly, what keeps me going is just this drive to finally get my MBA and prove to myself I can do it, especially after all the sacrifices my family has made for me to be here.

That’s incredibly admirable. It sounds like there’s a lot of personal meaning behind finishing your degree, and your perseverance is truly inspiring. How do you envision your life looking different if you’re able to push through and finish this last hurdle?

Hey, I appreciate that. I guess I see myself finally feeling accomplished, like I’ve done something big for myself and my family, and maybe even getting a job that lets me give back to them after all they’ve done for me.

It's clear that finishing your MBA is deeply important to you and your family, and it's inspiring to see you holding onto that vision despite the challenges. Can you tell me more about what gives you hope that you'll be able to push through and reach that goal?

Hey, thanks for recognizing how much this means to me. I think what gives me hope is knowing I’ve made it this far already, and even with everything going on, I still have this stubborn part of me that doesn’t want to give up now.

It sounds like that stubborn determination is a real strength for you, and it’s understandable that you don’t want to give up now, especially after all you’ve accomplished and the sacrifices you and your family have made. Can you tell me more about what you think would be the most meaningful part of reaching that goal for yourself and your family?

Hey, I’m glad you see that determination in me. Honestly, I think the most meaningful part would be showing my family that all their support wasn’t for nothing, and just being able to say I did it, you know, like a real win for all of us after so much struggle.

I can really feel how much this means to you and your family, and I'm in awe of the strength it takes to keep pushing forward through all the struggles. What steps do you think would help you get from where you are now to that moment of saying, 'I did it'?

Hey, thanks for seeing how much this matters to me. I think the next steps would be figuring out if I can salvage this class with some extra help or extensions, and maybe just taking it one day at a time to get back on track without overwhelming myself.

I really like how you're considering practical options, like salvaging the class or taking things one day at a time. Have you thought about any specific ways to tackle the extra help or extensions, or maybe what support systems you might lean on to keep from feeling overwhelmed?

Hey, I’m glad you think that approach makes sense. I guess I could start by talking to my professor about any makeup work or extensions, and maybe see if there are tutoring resources or classmates who could help me catch up, while also leaning on friends or family for emotional support to keep me grounded.

That's a solid plan, and I appreciate how you're thinking through both the academic and emotional support you might need. Have you thought about how you might approach your professor or tutoring resources specifically, and what kind of emotional support from friends or family would be most helpful to you?

Hey, I’m glad you think the plan sounds solid. I think with my professor, I’ll just be honest about what’s been going on and ask if there’s any way to make up the work or get some extra time, and for tutoring, I’ll check with the school’s academic resources to see what’s available; as for emotional support, just having friends or family to vent to or hang out with to take my mind off things would really help.

As we close this session, I want to emphasize how impressed I am by your determination and resilience in the face of such significant challenges. Your plan to approach your professor, seek academic support, and lean on friends and family is thoughtful and practical, and it shows your commitment to overcoming these hurdles.
Moving forward, I encourage you to stay focused on your goals and remember why this matters so much to you and your family. Celebrate each small victory along the way, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it.
Our next step will be to continue exploring coping strategies and building on the plan you've outlined today. Until then, remember to take care of yourself and trust in your ability to push through these difficult times. You've got this.
Hey, thanks for the encouragement and for seeing how hard I’m trying. I’ll definitely keep those reminders in mind and take it step by step.

{{"reasoning": "The session is naturally concluding with a clear next-step plan and emotional closure. The therapist has provided comprehensive support and the client feels acknowledged and encouraged.", "determination": "stop"}}
